Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 08:51AM - edited Nov 3, 2008 08:52AM by jilly47 Cute kids! When something "big" is going on in a family, kids really pick up on it and I think what they imagine is sometimes worse than the actual facts. When my dad was dx with his cancer, we were honest with the kids, and answered their questions when they came up. We didn't go into alot of detail; they really didn't want that anyway.We just reassured their fears and let them talk openly about them. What I believe is that they need to trust that you will always tell them the truth. That way they can be reassured that something terrible isn't happening that you're not telling them. If you promise that you'll always be honest, and tell them that you'll let them know when it's time to worry, they can go on with the business of being a kid.

All the waitresses wear them.  Well, my cousin, who had a bi-lat , chemo and rads 3 years ago just went off on our server. She was really offended by the shirt. First, she said breast cancer isn't cute so the term boobies is stupid,  and second, as a person who chose NOT to save her boobies in hoping for a cure, the shirt sends a mixed message. Yeah, she got that the shirt didn't mean save in a literal way, but she was making a point.  In the same vein, could you imagine a t-shirt for testicular cancer with a penis and testicles and the words SAVE THE BOYS--it cracks me up just thinking about it!
